"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that the United States is facing a crisis in writing skills, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills result in high private-sector costs for training. Writing is crucial for employment and promotion, and is a key feature in educational standards. The National Writing Project has been the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools since 1973. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, is the sole national program addressing writing issues in schools. Evaluations show improved student writing performance and classroom practices. It serves as a model for enhancing teaching in various subjects and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually in 200 sites across the US. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, aims to expand its network of sites across the US to provide teachers with access to writing programs. The program focuses on maintaining high-quality sites, disseminating effective practices, and coordinating activities with other educational initiatives. SEC. 2332 focuses on maintaining high-quality sites, disseminating effective practices, and coordinating activities with other educational initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization focused on improving student writing and learning. The grant requires the organization to work with educational providers to establish teacher training programs for effective writing instruction. The National Writing Project will work with contractors to establish teacher training programs for effective writing instruction. The Secretary will provide funds for the programs, and the grantee must meet specified conditions and standards. The teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will be conducted year-round, train teachers from kindergarten to college, select teachers for a National Writing Project network, and encourage teachers from all disciplines to participate. The Federal share for teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) is 50% of the costs to the contractor, with a maximum limit of $150,000 for any one contractor or $300,000 for a program. The Secretary can waive this requirement based on financial need as determined by the National Advisory Board. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board composed of national educational and writing leaders to oversee teacher training programs with a maximum Federal share of $150,000 per contractor or $300,000 for statewide programs. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board to advise on student writing issues, review programs, and support development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs, specifying funds expended and making results available to Congress. Funding limitation of $150,000 reserved for evaluation for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years. Application review process outlined. The National Writing Project will establish a Review Board to evaluate applications for assistance and recommend funding. The National Writing Project will establish a Review Board to evaluate and recommend funding for applications for assistance under this subsection. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for the following 5 years.
